elements.content: A new luminescent terbium–metal–organic framework [Tb3(L)2(HCOO)­(H2O)5]·DMF·4H2O (1) (H4L = 4,4′-(pyridine-3,5-diyl)­diisophthalic acid) has been successfully assembled by Tb3+ ions and an undeveloped pyridyl-tetracarboxylate. Compound 1 exhibits a 3D porous (3,8)-connected (4.52)2(42.512.66.75.83) topological framework with fascinating 1D open hydrophilic channels decorated by uncoordinated Lewis basic pyridyl nitrogen atoms. In particular, the Tb-MOF (1) can detect Cu2+ ions with high selectivity and sensitivity, and its luminescence is nearly entirely quenched in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) solution and biological system. In addition, 1 still has high detection for the trace content of nitromethane with 70 ppm, which suggests that 1 is a promising example of dual functional materials with sensing copper ions and nitromethane.

elements.content: The sensing and detection of metal ions and small molecules play a significant role in environmental science, medicinal science, life sciences, and the nuclear industry. Among all detection technologies, fluorometric methods have attracted much research interest due to their distinguishing advantages, i.e., short response time, high sensibility, simplicity, and the possibility to be used either in solid phase or in solution. Since Cu2+ is one of the most essential ions in living biosystems, particularly in the brain, the efficient, straightforward, and real time detection of a trace amount of Cu2+ in the biological systems will be helpful to understand the factors for related copper metabolism disordered Wilson’s disease and thus could provide possible methods for its treatment. In addition, the fast-growing activities from human society and industry have increasingly released many hazardous metal ions and toxic organic small molecules, which have been demonstrated to cause many serious adverse effects on people’s health and their habitat. Thus, it is extremely important and urgent to develop a new method to detect and sense small pollutants and metal cations through the naked eyes.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The sensing and detection of metal ions and small molecules play a significant role in environmental science, medicinal science, life sciences, and the nuclear industry. Among all detection technologies, fluorometric methods have attracted much research interest due to their distinguishing advantages, i.e., short response time, high sensibility, simplicity, and the possibility to be used either in solid phase or in solution. Since Cu2+ is one of the most essential ions in living biosystems, particularly in the brain, the efficient, straightforward, and real time detection of a trace amount of Cu2+ in the biological systems will be helpful to understand the factors for related copper metabolism disordered Wilson's disease and thus could provide possible methods for its treatment. In addition, the fast-growing activities from human society and industry have increasingly released many hazardous metal ions and toxic organic small molecules, which have been demonstrated to cause many serious adverse effects on people's health and their habitat. Thus, it is extremely important and urgent to develop a new method to detect and sense small pollutants and metal cations through the naked eyes.

elements.content: Given that some porous metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) can generate strong luminescent signals with visible emission colors, this type of MOF should be able to be developed as a new type of promising chemical sensors. In comparison to transition-metal-based MOFs, lanthanide-based metal–organic frameworks (Ln-MOFs) are particularly interesting for this type of application due to their unique optical properties including high color purity, large Stokes shift value, visible color with the naked eye, and relatively long luminescence lifetimes, which originally come from f–f transitions via an “antenna effect”. Before this research, a lot of luminescent Ln-MOFs-based materials with sensing functions have been reported and summarized in . For example, some Ln-MOFs reported by Chen and other groups have already shown their ability to detect metal ions and organic solvent molecules, respectively. In general, an efficient strategy to prepare MOF-based sensors is to introduce functional organic species into Lewis basic sites, where organic parts can act as luminescence groups while Lewis basic sites and π-conjugated backbones could provide the binding interactions for detection. Thus, the marriage of porosity and potential open sites (metal/organic group) within Ln-MOFs have endowed these materials with novel sensing functionality; for example, open Lewis basic pyridyl sites can respond to metal ions while open Ln3+ sites could sense small organic molecules. However, it is very challenging to realize open Lewis basic sites within porous MOFs because such Lewis basic sites are easily occupied by other metal cations to form condensed phases.

Before this research, a lot of luminescent Ln-MOFs-based materials with sensing functions have been reported and summarized in . For example, some Ln-MOFs reported by Chen and other groups have already shown their ability to detect metal ions and organic solvent molecules, respectively. Thus, the marriage of porosity and potential open sites (metal/organic group) within Ln-MOFs have endowed these materials with novel sensing functionality; for example, open Lewis basic pyridyl sites can respond to metal ions while open Ln3+ sites could sense small organic molecules. However, it is very challenging to realize open Lewis basic sites within porous MOFs because such Lewis basic sites are easily occupied by other metal cations to form condensed phases.

elements.content: Taking advantage of the excellent sensing properties of Ln-MOFs with the aforementioned ideas in mind, 4,4′-(pyridine-3,5-diyl)­diisophthalic acid (H4L) and Tb3+ were selected to construct porous Tb-MOFs for sensing of metal cations and organic molecules based on the following reasons: (i) An unsaturated (open) pyridyl group is an excellent functional site to respond to metal cations and small Lewis acidic molecules. (ii) As a rigid ligand, H4L has the advantage of forming robust porous frameworks. (iii) Tb3+ cations have a pure and sharp green emission arising from characteristic 4f electronic transitions, which can be employed as the sensitive optical signal. In this Article, we demonstrate a novel Tb-MOF, [Tb3(L)2(HCOO)­(H2O)5]·DMF·4H2O (1), based on the pyridyl-tetracarboxylate ligand. The as-prepared Tb-MOF possesses a porous luminescent robust framework with one-dimensional open hydrophilic channels decorated by uncoordinated pyridyl nitrogen atoms, providing a platform for luminescent sensing research. Compound 1 exhibits highly sensitive sensing of nitromethane and metal ions, especially for Cu2+ cation, one of the most important and essential metal cations in living biosystems.

All solvents and chemicals are purchased from a commercial company and directly used without further purification. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was studied on a Rigaku Ultima IV diffractometer (Cu Kα radiation, λ = 1.5406 Å). Thermogravimetric (TG) curves were performed on a NETZSCH 449C thermal analyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C min–1 under air atmosphere. Photoluminescence spectra were measured on a Hitachi F-4500 fluorescence spectrophotometer. FT-IR spectra (KBr pellets) were conducted on a Thermo Electron NEXUS 670 FTIR spectrometer. Elemental analyses were performed on a PerkinElmer 2400 Series II analyzer. The fluorescence lifetime was recorded using an Edinburgh Instruments FLS920 fluorescence spectrometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All solvents and chemicals are purchased from a commercial company and directly used without further purification. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was studied on a Rigaku Ultima IV diffractometer (Cu Kα radiation, λ = 1.5406 Å). Thermogravimetric (TG) curves were performed on a NETZSCH 449C thermal analyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 under air atmosphere. Photoluminescence spectra were measured on a Hitachi F-4500 fluorescence spectrophotometer. FT-IR spectra (KBr pellets) were conducted on a Thermo Electron NEXUS 670 FTIR spectrometer. Elemental analyses were performed on a PerkinElmer 2400 Series II analyzer. The fluorescence lifetime was recorded using an Edinburgh Instruments FLS920 fluorescence spectrometer.

elements.content: A mixture of Tb­(NO3)3·6H2O (45.3 mg, 0.1 mmol) and H4L (12.2 mg, 0.03 mmol) was dissolved in 6 mL of DMF–H2O (1:1 in v/v) with two drops of concentrated HNO3. The final mixture was put into a Parr Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (23 mL) and heated at 160 °C for 4 days. After the reaction mixture was slowly cooled to room temperature, colorless crystals were collected (yield: 82% based on Tb). Single-crystal X-ray structural determination, elemental analysis, and TGA determined that the formula of 1 should be [Tb3(L)2(HCOO)­(H2O)5]·DMF·4H2O. Anal. Calcd for 1: C 35.3, H 2.84, N 2.69%. Found: C 36.1, H 2.79, N 2.73%. FT-IR (KBr pellets, cm–1): 3440s, 3046m, 2825w, 2453w, 2356w, 1686s, 1657s, 1550s, 1493s, 1457s, 1371s, 1161w, 1008m, 921m, 829m, 783s, 696s, 573m.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Tb3(L)2(HCOO)(H2O)5]⋅DMF⋅4H2O (1)

A mixture of Tb(NO3)3⋅6H2O (45.3 mg, 0.1 mmol) and H4L (12.2 mg, 0.03 mmol) was dissolved in 6 mL of DMF-H2O (1:1 in v/v) with two drops of concentrated HNO3. The final mixture was put into a Parr Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (23 mL) and heated at 160 °C for 4 days. After the reaction mixture was slowly cooled to room temperature, colorless crystals were collected (yield: 82% based on Tb). Single-crystal X-ray structural determination, elemental analysis, and TGA determined that the formula of 1 should be [Tb3(L)2(HCOO)(H2O)5]⋅DMF⋅4H2O. Anal. Calcd for 1: C 35.3, H 2.84, N 2.69%. Found: C 36.1, H 2.79, N 2.73%. FT-IR (KBr pellets, cm-1): 3440s, 3046m, 2825w, 2453w, 2356w, 1686s, 1657s, 1550s, 1493s, 1457s, 1371s, 1161w, 1008m, 921m, 829m, 783s, 696s, 573m.

elements.content: The diffraction data for compound 1 was collected on a RigakuXtaLAB mini diffractometer with graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.710 73 Å) and were reduced using the program CrystalClear together with an empirical absorption correction. The crystal structure was solved through direct methods and refined based on F 2 by the full matrix least-squares methods using SHELXTL. All non-H atoms were refined anisotropically. The positions of hydrogen atoms attached to carbon atoms were generated geometrically. In 1 (CCDC: 1427795), the formate anions were generated during the synthesis by the hydrolysis of DMF; all the guests in the pores are highly disordered and cannot be identified by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The contribution of the disordered guests was subtracted from the reflection data by the PLATON/SQUEEZE method. The resulting new files were used to further refine the structure. Crystallographic data and other pertinent information for 1 are summarized in Table S1 in the Supporting Information, while the selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table S2 in the Supporting Information.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

The diffraction data for compound 1 was collected on a RigakuXtaLAB mini diffractometer with graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) and were reduced using the program CrystalClear  together with an empirical absorption correction. The crystal structure was solved through direct methods and refined based on F 2 by the full matrix least-squares methods using SHELXTL. All non-H atoms were refined anisotropically. The positions of hydrogen atoms attached to carbon atoms were generated geometrically. In 1 (CCDC: 1427795), the formate anions were generated during the synthesis by the hydrolysis of DMF; all the guests in the pores are highly disordered and cannot be identified by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The contribution of the disordered guests was subtracted from the reflection data by the PLATON/SQUEEZE method. The resulting new files were used to further refine the structure. Crystallographic data and other pertinent information for 1 are summarized in Table S1 in the Supporting Information, while the selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table S2 in the Supporting Information.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that 1 crystallizes in the tetragonal I4̅2d space group. The asymmetric unit contains one and a half Tb3+ ions, one L4– ligand, half of formate anion, as well as two and a half coordinated water molecules (Figure S1, Supporting Information). The formate anions are derived from the decomposition of DMF molecules. Tb1­(III) is nine-coordinated by one aqua ligand and eight O atoms of six carboxylate groups from four L4– ligands, forming a tricapped trigonal-pyramidal geometry. The Tb2­(III) center is eight-coordinated with a distorted dodecahedron geometry defined by five O atoms from four different carboxylate groups, one O atom from formate anion, and the remaining two O atoms from two individual aqua ligands. Compound 1 consists of the centrosymmetric linker trinuclear cluster subunits [Tb3(COO)8] (a) bridged through the branched organic linker L4– via carboxylate groups. Each L4– ligand coordinates to five Tb­(III) atoms through three different carboxylate groups adopting μ1-η1:η1, μ2-η1:η2, and μ2-η1:η1 coordination modes (b). As a result, the trinuclear clusters [Tb3(COO)8] were connected by L4– and formate anions to form a three-dimensional porous structure with a one-dimensional channel (c). Note that, viewed along the a-axis, the one-dimensional open channel has a dimension of about 17.709(7) × 3.216(3) Å2 (calculated by the distance between the pair of the symmetric pyridyl N1 atoms and O9 atoms in the pore, Figure S2, Supporting Information). From the topological viewpoint, the L4– ligand could be considered as a 3-connected node (Figure S3, Supporting Information) while the formate anion can be defined as a linker and the [Tb3(COO)8] cluster can be viewed as an 8-connected node (Figure S4, Supporting Information). Thus, the overall structure of 1 is a 3D (3,8)-connected framework with (4.52)2(42.512.66.75.83) topology (d). The 3D structure analyzed by PLATON shows a moderate void of 5183.4 Å3, which represents 40.1% of the volume of the unit cell (12 919.0 Å3) if all disordered solvent molecules were removed. The most significant structural feature of compound 1 is that it has free Lewis basic pyridyl sites within the pores, suggesting there might be some interactions between these sites and Lewis acidic analytes (e.g., metal ions and/or organic small molecules). Such interactions are anticipated to change the electronic structure of the L4– ligand, which dictates the energy transfer from ligand to Tb3+ cation and decides the overall sensing effectivity of the emissive lanthanide ion.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that 1 crystallizes in the tetragonal I4̅2d space group. The asymmetric unit contains one and a half Tb3+ ions, one L4- ligand, half of formate anion, as well as two and a half coordinated water molecules (Figure S1, Supporting Information). The formate anions are derived from the decomposition of DMF molecules. Tb1(III) is nine-coordinated by one aqua ligand and eight O atoms of six carboxylate groups from four L4- ligands, forming a tricapped trigonal-pyramidal geometry. The Tb2(III) center is eight-coordinated with a distorted dodecahedron geometry defined by five O atoms from four different carboxylate groups, one O atom from formate anion, and the remaining two O atoms from two individual aqua ligands. Compound 1 consists of the centrosymmetric linker trinuclear cluster subunits [Tb3(COO)8] (a) bridged through the branched organic linker L4- via carboxylate groups. Each L4- ligand coordinates to five Tb(III) atoms through three different carboxylate groups adopting μ1-η1:η1, μ2-η1:η2, and μ2-η1:η1 coordination modes (b). As a result, the trinuclear clusters [Tb3(COO)8] were connected by L4- and formate anions to form a three-dimensional porous structure with a one-dimensional channel (c). Note that, viewed along the a-axis, the one-dimensional open channel has a dimension of about 17.709(7) × 3.216(3) Å2 (calculated by the distance between the pair of the symmetric pyridyl N1 atoms and O9 atoms in the pore, Figure S2, Supporting Information). From the topological viewpoint, the L4- ligand could be considered as a 3-connected node (Figure S3, Supporting Information) while the formate anion can be defined as a linker and the [Tb3(COO)8] cluster can be viewed as an 8-connected node (Figure S4, Supporting Information). Thus, the overall structure of 1 is a 3D (3,8)-connected framework with (4.52)2(42.512.66.75.83) topology (d). The 3D structure analyzed by PLATON shows a moderate void of 5183.4 Å3, which represents 40.1% of the volume of the unit cell (12919.0 Å3) if all disordered solvent molecules were removed. The most significant structural feature of compound 1 is that it has free Lewis basic pyridyl sites within the pores, suggesting there might be some interactions between these sites and Lewis acidic analytes (e.g., metal ions and/or organic small molecules). Such interactions are anticipated to change the electronic structure of the L4- ligand, which dictates the energy transfer from ligand to Tb3+ cation and decides the overall sensing effectivity of the emissive lanthanide ion.

elements.content: Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) of 1 confirmed the phase purity of their bulk crystalline materials. As shown in Supporting Information (Figure S5), the peaks on the PXRD of as-synthesized samples of 1 are coincident with those on their respective simulated patterns. Considering practical applications, the robustness of compound 1 was first investigated. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) of compound 1 was conducted under air atmosphere from room temperature to 800 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C min–1. As shown in Figure S6 (Supporting Information), the weight loss of 14.2% (calcd 14.4%) corresponds to the loss of all DMF and water molecules in the range 25–420 °C. The PXRD experiments under different temperatures have been conducted to study the thermal stability of compound 1 upon the removal of guest molecules according to the TG analysis. The PXRD patterns suggest that the desolvated framework 1 can be stable up to ∼420 °C (Figure S7, Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text:
PXRD and Thermal Stabilities of 1 

Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) of 1 confirmed the phase purity of their bulk crystalline materials. As shown in Supporting Information (Figure S5), the peaks on the PXRD of as-synthesized samples of 1 are coincident with those on their respective simulated patterns. Considering practical applications, the robustness of compound 1 was first investigated. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) of compound 1 was conducted under air atmosphere from room temperature to 800 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. As shown in Figure S6 (Supporting Information), the weight loss of 14.2% (calcd 14.4%) corresponds to the loss of all DMF and water molecules in the range 25-420 °C. The PXRD experiments under different temperatures have been conducted to study the thermal stability of compound 1 upon the removal of guest molecules according to the TG analysis. The PXRD patterns suggest that the desolvated framework 1 can be stable up to ~420 °C (Figure S7, Supporting Information).

elements.content: shows the excitation and photoluminescence (PL) spectra of compound 1. The excitation peaks at ∼327 nm can be assigned to the π → π* and n →π* electron transition of L ligands, and those from 350 to 390 nm are ascribed to the f–f transitions of the Tb3+ ion (Figure S8, Supporting Information). The emission spectrum of compound 1 (excitation wavelength: 327 nm) indicates the well-resolved magnified luminescence of the f–f transitions, which is contributed from the energy transfer from L ligands to Tb3+ ions. The evident characteristic transitions of the Tb3+ ion in compound 1 can be seen at 491, 545, 585, and 621 nm, which are contributed from the 5D4 → 7F6, 5D4 → 7F5, 5D4 → 7F4, and 5D4 → 7F3 f–f transitions, respectively. The decay lifetime of compound 1 is 1095.25 μs (Figure S9, Supporting Information), which is significantly higher in comparison with the reported MOFs.

elements.content: To study the sensing ability of compound 1 to different metal cations through its luminescence, compound 1 samples (50 mg) have been dispersed in different DMF solutions (10 mL) containing 10–2 M of M­(NO3) x (M = Na+, K+, Ag+, Mg2+, Ca2+, Mn2+, Co2+, Cu2+, Zn2+, Cd2+, Pb2+, Ni2+, and Al3+). Before testing their photoluminescence, all suspensions were sonicated for 30 min to ensure even dispersion. The most interesting feature is that the luminescence intensity of the metal ion incorporated DMF suspension is heavily dependent on the species of metals. Interestingly, Cu2+ exhibits a drastic quenching effect on the luminescence of 1, while other metal ions have no significant effect on the emission with the exception of Cu2+, which enhances or decreases luminescence intensity to a degree (a). The different effects on the emission between Cu2+ and other cations are clearly observed, indicative of the fact that 1 can be considered as a promising luminescent probe for Cu2+ ions. The luminescence intensity of the Cu2+ incorporated 1 is more than 21 times weaker than that with no metal ion incorporated 1 (b). This unique quenching effect in 1 possibly results from the stronger affinity of pyridine N atoms in L4– toward Cu2+, as well as the smaller ionic radius of Cu2+, which renders Cu2+ ions more readily able to make contact with the pyridine N atoms than Mn2+, Ni2+, Co2+, and other ions and, as a result, decreases the efficiency of energy transfer from L4– ligands to f–f transitions of Tb3+ centers. Quantitatively, this quenching effect can be explained by the Stern–Volmer equation: I 0/I = 1 + K sv[M], where I 0 and I are the luminescence intensity of metal-ion-free 1 and metal-ion-incorporated 1, respectively, [M] is the molar concentration of the metal ion, and K sv is the quenching effect coefficient of the metal ion. It is thus expected that the reduction in luminescence intensity is proportional to the concentration of the metal cation. K sv was calculated from the experimental data for the examined ions (Table S3, Supporting Information). Moreover, to explore the detection limit of 1 as a Cu2+ probe, Cu2+ with different concentrations in DMF solutions were dropped into a suspension of 1 to form a series of suspensions of Cu2+-1in DMF (10–6–10–2 mol/L). As shown in , the luminescence intensity of 1 gradually decreases with increasing concentration of Cu2+ such that the probe can reach 10–6 mol/L. As illustrated in Table S4 (Supporting Information) the high K sv value of 2021.8 M–1 for Cu2+ is greatly enhanced compared with that of the reported Ln-MOFs sensors. The K sv value of 1 is about higher six times than that of {[Tb4(μ3OH)4­(BPDC)3(BPDCA)0.5­(H2O)6]­ClO4·5H2O.
elements.clean_text:
Sensing of Metal Ions

To study the sensing ability of compound 1 to different metal cations through its luminescence, compound 1 samples (50 mg) have been dispersed in different DMF solutions (10 mL) containing 10-2 M of M(NO3) x  (M = Na+, K+, Ag+, Mg2+, Ca2+, Mn2+, Co2+, Cu2+, Zn2+, Cd2+, Pb2+, Ni2+, and Al3+). Before testing their photoluminescence, all suspensions were sonicated for 30 min to ensure even dispersion. The most interesting feature is that the luminescence intensity of the metal ion incorporated DMF suspension is heavily dependent on the species of metals. Interestingly, Cu2+ exhibits a drastic quenching effect on the luminescence of 1, while other metal ions have no significant effect on the emission with the exception of Cu2+, which enhances or decreases luminescence intensity to a degree (a). The different effects on the emission between Cu2+ and other cations are clearly observed, indicative of the fact that 1 can be considered as a promising luminescent probe for Cu2+ ions. The luminescence intensity of the Cu2+ incorporated 1 is more than 21 times weaker than that with no metal ion incorporated 1 (b). This unique quenching effect in 1 possibly results from the stronger affinity of pyridine N atoms in L4- toward Cu2+, as well as the smaller ionic radius of Cu2+, which renders Cu2+ ions more readily able to make contact with the pyridine N atoms than Mn2+, Ni2+, Co2+, and other ions and, as a result, decreases the efficiency of energy transfer from L4- ligands to f-f transitions of Tb3+ centers. Quantitatively, this quenching effect can be explained by the Stern-Volmer equation: I 0/I = 1 + K sv[M], where I 0 and I are the luminescence intensity of metal-ion-free 1 and metal-ion-incorporated 1, respectively, [M] is the molar concentration of the metal ion, and K sv is the quenching effect coefficient of the metal ion. It is thus expected that the reduction in luminescence intensity is proportional to the concentration of the metal cation. K sv was calculated from the experimental data for the examined ions (Table S3, Supporting Information). Moreover, to explore the detection limit of 1 as a Cu2+ probe, Cu2+ with different concentrations in DMF solutions were dropped into a suspension of 1 to form a series of suspensions of Cu2+-1in DMF (10-6-10-2 mol/L). As shown in , the luminescence intensity of 1 gradually decreases with increasing concentration of Cu2+ such that the probe can reach 10-6 mol/L. As illustrated in Table S4 (Supporting Information) the high K sv value of 2021.8 M-1 for Cu2+ is greatly enhanced compared with that of the reported Ln-MOFs sensors. The K sv value of 1 is about higher six times than that of {[Tb4(μ3OH)4(BPDC)3(BPDCA)0.5(H2O)6]ClO4⋅5H2O.

elements.content: To further explore the potential application of such a luminescent MOF sensor in a biosystem, the sensing function of compound 1 under simulated physiological conditions has been carried out. A physiological aqueous buffer solution was prepared by dissolving 4-(2-hydroxyethyl)­piperazine-1-ethanesulfonic acid (HEPES) into water to form an aqueous solution (0.02 M, pH = 7) to mimic the living cell environment (Figure S10, Supporting Information). Dehydrated 1 was dispersed in the above-prepared solution with different amounts of Cu­(NO3)2. As shown in , the sensing function of 1 for Cu2+ ion in the above physiological solutions is comparable to that of 1 observed in pure aqueous solution, supporting the possibility of compound 1 for detection of Cu2+ cation in biosystem.

elements.content: The adverse impact of persistent organic pollutants on the environment and health are serious. As promising novel sensing compounds, luminescent Ln-MOFs have been widely employed to recognize organic small pollutants in the biosystem and environment through the change of obvious luminescent signals caused by these pollutants. Due to their complicated structural factors, one can predict that it is reasonable to repalce solvent molecules with other different organic solvent molecules. To explore the potential function of 1 for the sensing of small organic molecules, several analyte molecules, such as nitromethane (NM), acetone, benzene, N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP), isopropanol (IPA), petroleum ether (PE), dichloromethane (CH2Cl2), isopropanol (IPA), DMF, methanol (MeOH), DMA, ethanol (EtOH), and DMSO, were investigated. As shown in , the emission intensities of the emission peaks largely depend on the solvent molecules, especially nitromethane, which shows a significant quenching effect. Such solvent-dependent quenching behavior is very important to sense nitromethane molecules, and thus, it should be examined in detail. A batch of emulsions of 1 in DMF with gradually increasing nitromethane concentrations was prepared to monitor emissive responses. It was found that the luminescent intensity of the suspension of 1 decreased with the addition of nitromethane, which almost disappeared at the content of 70 ppm (a,b). The fluorescence decrease was nearly proportional to the nitromethane concentration. The decreasing trend of the fluorescence intensity at 545 nm for 1 versus the volume ratio of nitromethane could be well-fit with a first-order exponential decay (Figure S11, Supporting Information), indicating that fluorescence quenching of compound 1 by nitromethane is controlled by diffusion.
elements.clean_text:
Sensing of Organic Small Molecules

The adverse impact of persistent organic pollutants on the environment and health are serious. As promising novel sensing compounds, luminescent Ln-MOFs have been widely employed to recognize organic small pollutants in the biosystem and environment through the change of obvious luminescent signals caused by these pollutants. Due to their complicated structural factors, one can predict that it is reasonable to repalce solvent molecules with other different organic solvent molecules. To explore the potential function of 1 for the sensing of small organic molecules, several analyte molecules, such as nitromethane (NM), acetone, benzene, N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP), isopropanol (IPA), petroleum ether (PE), dichloromethane (CH2Cl2), isopropanol (IPA), DMF, methanol (MeOH), DMA, ethanol (EtOH), and DMSO, were investigated. As shown in , the emission intensities of the emission peaks largely depend on the solvent molecules, especially nitromethane, which shows a significant quenching effect. Such solvent-dependent quenching behavior is very important to sense nitromethane molecules, and thus, it should be examined in detail. A batch of emulsions of 1 in DMF with gradually increasing nitromethane concentrations was prepared to monitor emissive responses. It was found that the luminescent intensity of the suspension of 1 decreased with the addition of nitromethane, which almost disappeared at the content of 70 ppm (a,b). The fluorescence decrease was nearly proportional to the nitromethane concentration. The decreasing trend of the fluorescence intensity at 545 nm for 1 versus the volume ratio of nitromethane could be well-fit with a first-order exponential decay (Figure S11, Supporting Information), indicating that fluorescence quenching of compound 1 by nitromethane is controlled by diffusion.

elements.content: The luminescence quenching mechanism induced by metal ions might be explained by the donor–acceptor electron transfer effect from ligands to metal centers. The weak bonding between Cu2+ and the N atom site of the organic ligand might partly quench the singlet and triplet excited states of the ligand-to-Tb3+ optically active core. Because alkali and alkaline earth cations have saturated electron configuration, they almost have no effect on the luminescent intensity while Zn2+/Cd2+ cations display a light quenching effect due to the weak interaction between Lewis basic sites and metal cations. Since other different metal cations have a different unsaturated electron configuration, they might generate the different quenching effects on the luminescent intensity. The microporosity of 1 might also increase the interaction between the pyridyl Lewis basic sites and Cu2+ cations. Note that such interactions can decrease the ligands’ antenna efficiency and further magnify the f–f transitions of Tb3+ cations, resulting in the luminescence’s quenching. Although a similar donor–acceptor electron transfer mechanism to explain the decreasing of luminescent intensity has been proposed in the previously reported Ln-MOFs materials, the deep understanding of such enhancing and quenching effects is still unclear. However, the effect of guest organic small molecules on ligand-to-metal energy transformation (LMET) plays a key role, because the emission efficiency of LMET determine the luminescent intensity. Since nitromethane is an organic acid due to the strong electron-withdrawing substituent nitro group, it can gradually move to the bare pyridyl Lewis basic sites in the channel, which obviously decrease the LMET efficiency and reduce the luminescent intensity.
elements.clean_text:
Mechanism of Luminescence Quenching Response

The luminescence quenching mechanism induced by metal ions might be explained by the donor-acceptor electron transfer effect from ligands to metal centers. The weak bonding between Cu2+ and the N atom site of the organic ligand might partly quench the singlet and triplet excited states of the ligand-to-Tb3+ optically active core. Because alkali and alkaline earth cations have saturated electron configuration, they almost have no effect on the luminescent intensity while Zn2+/Cd2+ cations display a light quenching effect due to the weak interaction between Lewis basic sites and metal cations. Since other different metal cations have a different unsaturated electron configuration, they might generate the different quenching effects on the luminescent intensity. The microporosity of 1 might also increase the interaction between the pyridyl Lewis basic sites and Cu2+ cations. Note that such interactions can decrease the ligands' antenna efficiency and further magnify the f-f transitions of Tb3+ cations, resulting in the luminescence's quenching. Although a similar donor-acceptor electron transfer mechanism to explain the decreasing of luminescent intensity has been proposed in the previously reported Ln-MOFs materials, the deep understanding of such enhancing and quenching effects is still unclear. However, the effect of guest organic small molecules on ligand-to-metal energy transformation (LMET) plays a key role, because the emission efficiency of LMET determine the luminescent intensity. Since nitromethane is an organic acid due to the strong electron-withdrawing substituent nitro group, it can gradually move to the bare pyridyl Lewis basic sites in the channel, which obviously decrease the LMET efficiency and reduce the luminescent intensity.

elements.content: In summary, a porous Tb-MOF (1) has been demonstrated as a luminescent probe with multifunctional sensitivity to sense small molecules and metal cations. Compound 1 features a 3D (3,8)-connected (4.52)2(42.512.66.75.83) topological framework with 1D Lewis basic pyridyl site-decorated open channel. Our results demonstrate that the luminescence intensities of compound 1 are highly sensitive to the Cu2+ ion. Clearly, porous MOFs decorated with bare Lewis basic sites are very promising as luminescent probes to selectively detect metal cations. Moreover, compound 1 also has high detection ability for trace content of nitromethane (as low as 70 ppm). It is expected that introducing the bare Lewis basic sites into functional luminescent Ln-MOFs may generate more highly sensitive sensors for small molecules, metal cations, and anions. These studies are still underway in our group.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, a porous Tb-MOF (1) has been demonstrated as a luminescent probe with multifunctional sensitivity to sense small molecules and metal cations. Compound 1 features a 3D (3,8)-connected (4.52)2(42.512.66.75.83) topological framework with 1D Lewis basic pyridyl site-decorated open channel. Our results demonstrate that the luminescence intensities of compound 1 are highly sensitive to the Cu2+ ion. Clearly, porous MOFs decorated with bare Lewis basic sites are very promising as luminescent probes to selectively detect metal cations. Moreover, compound 1 also has high detection ability for trace content of nitromethane (as low as 70 ppm). It is expected that introducing the bare Lewis basic sites into functional luminescent Ln-MOFs may generate more highly sensitive sensors for small molecules, metal cations, and anions. These studies are still underway in our group.

cln_elements.content: A mixture of Tb­(NO3)3·6H2O (45.3 mg, 0.1 mmol) and H4L (12.2 mg, 0.03 mmol) was dissolved in 6 mL of DMF–H2O (1:1 in v/v) with two drops of concentrated HNO3. The final mixture was put into a Parr Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (23 mL) and heated at 160 °C for 4 days. After the reaction mixture was slowly cooled to room temperature, colorless crystals were collected (yield: 82% based on Tb). Single-crystal X-ray structural determination, elemental analysis, and TGA determined that the formula of 1 should be [Tb3(L)2(HCOO)­(H2O)5]·DMF·4H2O. Anal. Calcd for 1: C 35.3, H 2.84, N 2.69%. Found: C 36.1, H 2.79, N 2.73%. FT-IR (KBr pellets, cm–1): 3440s, 3046m, 2825w, 2453w, 2356w, 1686s, 1657s, 1550s, 1493s, 1457s, 1371s, 1161w, 1008m, 921m, 829m, 783s, 696s, 573m.

Synthesis of [Tb3(L)2(HCOO)(H2O)5]⋅DMF⋅4H2O (1)

A mixture of Tb(NO3)3⋅6H2O (45.3 mg, 0.1 mmol) and H4L (12.2 mg, 0.03 mmol) was dissolved in 6 mL of DMF-H2O (1:1 in v/v) with two drops of concentrated HNO3. The final mixture was put into a Parr Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (23 mL) and heated at 160 °C for 4 days. After the reaction mixture was slowly cooled to room temperature, colorless crystals were collected (yield: 82% based on Tb). Single-crystal X-ray structural determination, elemental analysis, and TGA determined that the formula of 1 should be [Tb3(L)2(HCOO)(H2O)5]⋅DMF⋅4H2O. Anal. Calcd for 1: C 35.3, H 2.84, N 2.69%. Found: C 36.1, H 2.79, N 2.73%. FT-IR (KBr pellets, cm-1): 3440s, 3046m, 2825w, 2453w, 2356w, 1686s, 1657s, 1550s, 1493s, 1457s, 1371s, 1161w, 1008m, 921m, 829m, 783s, 696s, 573m.

cln_elements.content:
Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that 1 crystallizes in the tetragonal I4̅2d space group. The asymmetric unit contains one and a half Tb3+ ions, one L4– ligand, half of formate anion, as well as two and a half coordinated water molecules (Figure S1, Supporting Information). The formate anions are derived from the decomposition of DMF molecules. Tb1­(III) is nine-coordinated by one aqua ligand and eight O atoms of six carboxylate groups from four L4– ligands, forming a tricapped trigonal-pyramidal geometry. The Tb2­(III) center is eight-coordinated with a distorted dodecahedron geometry defined by five O atoms from four different carboxylate groups, one O atom from formate anion, and the remaining two O atoms from two individual aqua ligands. Compound 1 consists of the centrosymmetric linker trinuclear cluster subunits [Tb3(COO)8] (a) bridged through the branched organic linker L4– via carboxylate groups. Each L4– ligand coordinates to five Tb­(III) atoms through three different carboxylate groups adopting μ1-η1:η1, μ2-η1:η2, and μ2-η1:η1 coordination modes (b). As a result, the trinuclear clusters [Tb3(COO)8] were connected by L4– and formate anions to form a three-dimensional porous structure with a one-dimensional channel (c). Note that, viewed along the a-axis, the one-dimensional open channel has a dimension of about 17.709(7) × 3.216(3) Å2 (calculated by the distance between the pair of the symmetric pyridyl N1 atoms and O9 atoms in the pore, Figure S2, Supporting Information). From the topological viewpoint, the L4– ligand could be considered as a 3-connected node (Figure S3, Supporting Information) while the formate anion can be defined as a linker and the [Tb3(COO)8] cluster can be viewed as an 8-connected node (Figure S4, Supporting Information). Thus, the overall structure of 1 is a 3D (3,8)-connected framework with (4.52)2(42.512.66.75.83) topology (d). The 3D structure analyzed by PLATON shows a moderate void of 5183.4 Å3, which represents 40.1% of the volume of the unit cell (12 919.0 Å3) if all disordered solvent molecules were removed. The most significant structural feature of compound 1 is that it has free Lewis basic pyridyl sites within the pores, suggesting there might be some interactions between these sites and Lewis acidic analytes (e.g., metal ions and/or organic small molecules). Such interactions are anticipated to change the electronic structure of the L4– ligand, which dictates the energy transfer from ligand to Tb3+ cation and decides the overall sensing effectivity of the emissive lanthanide ion.

PXRD and Thermal Stabilities of <bold>1</bold>

Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) of 1 confirmed the phase purity of their bulk crystalline materials. As shown in Supporting Information (Figure S5), the peaks on the PXRD of as-synthesized samples of 1 are coincident with those on their respective simulated patterns. Considering practical applications, the robustness of compound 1 was first investigated. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) of compound 1 was conducted under air atmosphere from room temperature to 800 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C min–1. As shown in Figure S6 (Supporting Information), the weight loss of 14.2% (calcd 14.4%) corresponds to the loss of all DMF and water molecules in the range 25–420 °C. The PXRD experiments under different temperatures have been conducted to study the thermal stability of compound 1 upon the removal of guest molecules according to the TG analysis. The PXRD patterns suggest that the desolvated framework 1 can be stable up to ∼420 °C (Figure S7, Supporting Information).
